an3.127:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
an3.127:1.2: Then, late at night, the glorious god Hatthaka, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha. Thinking,
an3.127:1.3: “I will stand before the Buddha,” he sank and melted down, and wasn’t able to stay still.
an3.127:1.4: It’s like when ghee or oil is poured on sand, it sinks and melts down, and can’t remain stable.
an3.127:2.1: Then the Buddha said to Hatthaka,
an3.127:2.3: “Yes, sir,” replied Hatthaka. He manifested in a solid life-form, bowed to the Buddha, and stood to one side.
an3.127:3.1: “Hatthaka, I wonder whether you still rehearse now the teachings that you rehearsed when you were a human being?”
an3.127:3.2: “I still rehearse now the teachings that I rehearsed as a human being.
an3.127:3.3: And I also rehearse teachings that I didn’t rehearse as a human being.
an3.127:3.4: Just as the Buddha these days lives crowded by monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen; by rulers and their ministers, and teachers of other paths and their disciples,
an3.127:3.5: so I live crowded by the gods.
an3.127:3.6: The gods come from far away, thinking, ‘We’ll hear the teaching in the presence of Hatthaka.’
an3.127:3.7: Sir, I passed away without getting enough of three things.
an3.127:3.12: I passed away without getting enough of these three things.
an3.127:5.2: loving to hear the true teaching,
an3.127:5.3: Hatthaka has gone to the Aviha realm
an3.127:5.4: without getting enough of these three things.”
